cons:
Most staff regardless of discipline are expected to work above and beyond their hours.  Nursing staff regularly work through breaks.  Most wards are under staffed on a daily basis, which effects patient activities.  MDT are expected to cover shortfall in nursing staff.   I have seen an increase in staff going off with stress due to unrealistic demands and lack of support in the last six months. 

If you disagree or raise concerns with the Hospital Managers above ward level they can bully/ pressure you and be very negative.  They do not offer support to teams when there are issues, only focus on the negatives.    Seem out of touch with the teams and patients.

Focus is on keeping beds full due to a reduction in admissions over the last year, which has lead to decrease in revenue.    Very much run to make money even though it is a charity.  

Staff perks have declined over the last few years; yearly parties have been cut, pay awards are much lower than when I started.

review_title: A HR Perspective: Bullying is rife
pros: You will come across the most genuine people at St Andrews, far and few between but some have a heart of gold, cherish them if you're thinking of working at St Andrews as you will need their emotional support! There are some pro's, they have a Cycle to Work scheme, support groups set up such as Race and LGBT and on site canteen facilities.
cons:
In terms of Company value's, what is written isn't what they follow. Whilst working in HR, it's clear that discrimination and bullying is rife. The Charity protects senior managers who are discriminatory and then cover up the allegations and hide behind 'confidentiality' to the injured party. I've seen it happen with my own eyes. The senior HR team rule with fear and so are never challenged on decisions, idea's, practices or management style. Growth, in HR the gaps between roles are so large you'll never progress unless your personally liked, regardless of skills, abilities or merits, furthermore, they do not invest in their own, they will happily recruit externally when there is enough talent internally to fill a position. If you raise a discrimination claim, either be ready to be told 'we will look into it', or be suspended and investigated for how you raise the claim! Additionally, with working in HR, the way managers within HR would manage their teams and staff was disgusting, I can't imagine how the rest of the organisation is behaving, if not even HR can manage in an ethical manner. In terms of the role, the amount of work is completely disproportionate to the amount of hours / your salary and banding you are paid, you are expected to get work done regardless if that means staying until 8pm at night, or working at the weekends, when you challenge this, like I did - you get the response of ''you need to get the work completed''. 

A colleague told me something that will stick with me for life, they said that they were told by a member of staff that it was a Master / Slave relationship. In terms of Equality and Diversity, you can count the amount of BME Managers on two hands, and on one hand those that are Senior Managers, doesn't that say it all?

review_title: Worst employment experience of my life
pros: Nice grounds, patients and staff are motivated a motivated for the sake of the vulnerable patients.
cons:
Bullying is rife, it seems fully acceptable to shout at staff for being unwell. 
The business was not able too support or provide reasonable adjustments for long term disability, which had been supported by other employers, response was eye rolling, huffing and either walking off or blaming me for being in significant pain caused due to their failures to provide simple adjustments. 
The strategic approach is flimsy, decisions for multi million pound changes are made on rhetoric and who shouts the loudest/is the biggest personality, rather than reviewing and assessing options using sound evaluation of risk, opportunities and threats. The business makes a lot of noise about wanting to be creative, innovative and involve staff at all levels. However, this is only lip service and staff who put forward ideas, or speak “above their level of seniority” are essentially sanctioned for this. They state a want for innovation but create an environment where this is impossible. In my time there I repeatedly came accross confidential patient data being stored in locations outside of the standard record systems, where non clinical staff could access it. When this was reported to the internal data protection team rather than address th issue and contact the ICO the staff made a point of saying that they didn’t want to contact them because it created too much work as the ICO look closely. 
I have also been told by individuals working there that senior leaders have thrown solid (and potentially heavy ) objects at them because they don’t agree with creative contributions in meetings.
